profileText: A Representative from Alabama; born in Birmingham, Ala., April 9, 1942; graduated from Western-Olin High School, Birmingham, Ala., 1960; B.A., Morehouse College, Atlanta, Ga., 1964; J.D., Howard University, Washington, D.C., 1967; M.B.A., Atlanta University, Atlanta, Ga., 1970; lawyer, private practice; member of the Alabama state house of representatives, 1974-1980; member of the Alabama state senate, 1981-1992; elected as a Democrat to the One Hundred Third and to the four succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1993-January 3, 2003); unsuccessful candidate for nomination to the One Hundred Eighth Congress in 2002.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: "Earl Frederick Hilliard" in Black Americans in Congress, 1870-2007. Prepared under the direction of the Committee on House Administration by the Office of History & Preservation, U. S. House of Representatives. Washington: Government Printing Office, 2008.

researchRecord.name: ca. 1994-1996, amount unknown.
researchRecord.description: The interview with Rep. Earl Hilliard as part of the Voting Rights Act Oral History Project. Topics covered include Earl Hilliard's service to the Alabama House of Representatives and the Alabama Black Legislative Caucus, as well as his contributions to the United States Congress. The interview also traces the importance of the Voting Rights Act, the challenge of redistricting in Alabama, and Hilliard's leadership on issues involving public works.
